have.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: used with past participles to form perfect tenses
have.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: We’ve been spending too much money.
I hadn’t seen him for 15 years.
‘I hope you’ve read the instructions.’ ‘Yes, of course I have.’
You haven’t done much, have you?
have.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: used to say what someone or something looks like, what qualities or features they possess etc
have.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: She has dark hair and brown eyes.
Sullivan’s music does have a certain charm.
You need to have a lot of patience to be a teacher.
Wild rice has a very nutty flavour.
He didn’t even have the courtesy to answer my letter.
You should have seen the way Dad was dancing – I didn’t know he had it in him!
have.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to include or contain something or a particular number of things or people
have.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Japan has a population of over 120 million.
How many pages has it got?
The tank still has water in it.
have.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: used to say that someone owns something or that it is available for them to use
have.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: They used to have a Mercedes Benz.
Has your secretary got a fax machine?
Have you ever had your own business?
He’s a lovely dog – how long have you had him?
Can I have the car tonight, Dad?
have.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to be holding something or carrying it with you
have.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Look out! He’s got a gun.
Have you got any money on you?
I’m afraid I don’t have my address book with me.
have.translation[1].definitions[3].note_: Senses 1-4 of have are not used in the progressive
have.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: We were just having a look around.
Are you going to have a swim?
have.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: to eat, drink, or smoke something
have.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: She sat down and had another drink.
Someone had been having a cigarette in the toilet.
I usually have breakfast at about seven o'clock.
have.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: to experience something or be affected by something
have.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: We’ve been having a lot of difficulties with our new computer system.
I’m afraid your son has had a serious accident.
He is in hospital having treatment for a knee injury.
I hope you have a good holiday.
Thanks for everything – we had a great time.
He found it quite natural to have people fussing over him.
have.translation[1].definitions[7].defin: to think of something or to experience a particular feeling
have.translation[1].definitions[7].examp: If you have any good ideas for presents, let me know.
I have lots of happy memories of my time in Japan.
He had an awful feeling of guilt.
have.translation[1].definitions[8].defin: to suffer from a disease, injury, or pain
have.translation[1].definitions[8].examp: One of the victims had a broken leg.
have.translation[1].definitions[9].defin: if you have a particular amount of time, it is available for you to do something
have.translation[1].definitions[9].examp: You have just 30 seconds to answer the question.
I haven’t time to stop and talk just now.
have.translation[1].definitions[10].exam: I had lots of phone calls.
Have you had any news yet from Graham?
I expect he had some help from his father.
have.translation[1].definitions[11].defi: used to say that your body or something else is in a particular position or state, because you moved or did something
have.translation[1].definitions[11].exam: Janice likes to have the window open.
She had her back to the door.
He’s always got the stereo playing.
have.translation[1].definitions[12].defi: used to say that there is someone who is your relation or friend
have.translation[1].definitions[12].exam: She has an uncle in Wisconsin.
It was nice for Alice to have friends of her own age.
have.translation[1].definitions[13].defi: to be employed in a particular job or to be responsible for doing something
have.translation[1].definitions[13].exam: Her boyfriend has a well-paid job.
The headteacher has responsibility for the management of the school.
I can’t stand here talking – I have work to do  (=there is work that I must do).
have.translation[1].definitions[14].defi: to employ or be in charge of a group of workers
have.translation[1].definitions[14].exam: Margaret Gillies currently has a team of 20 volunteers working for her.
have.translation[1].definitions[15].defi: if a shop or a hotel has goods or rooms, they are available for you to buy or use
have.translation[1].definitions[15].exam: Do you have any single rooms?
They didn’t have any sweaters in my size.
have.translation[1].definitions[16].defi: to hold someone violently by a part of their body
have.translation[1].definitions[16].exam: They had him by the throat.
have.translation[1].definitions[17].defi: if you have visitors or guests, they have come to your home, office etc
have.translation[1].definitions[17].exam: Sorry, I didn’t realize you had visitors.
We had friends to stay over the weekend.
have.translation[1].definitions[18].defi: if you have an event such as a meeting, party, or concert, it happens because you have organized it
have.translation[1].definitions[18].exam: We’re having a party on Saturday – you’re very welcome to come.
have.translation[1].definitions[19].exam: a mistake that could have disastrous results
Cardew was having a bad influence on the other students.
have.translation[1].definitions[20].defi: used to say that an opportunity or choice is available for you
have.translation[1].definitions[20].exam: If you have the chance, you should go and see it – it’s a really good film.
Women managers have a choice as to whether they wear trousers or a skirt.
Last year I had the honour of meeting the Prince of Wales.
have.translation[1].definitions[21].defi: if a woman has a baby, it is born from her body
have.translation[1].definitions[21].exam: Anna insisted on having the baby at home.
have.translation[1].definitions[22].defi: to affect someone in a way that makes them start doing something
have.translation[1].definitions[22].exam: Within minutes he had the whole audience laughing and clapping.
have.translation[1].definitions[23].defi: to persuade or order someone to do something
have.translation[1].definitions[23].exam: She had me doing all kinds of jobs for her.
I’ll have Hudson show you to your room.
have.translation[1].definitions[24].exam: I expect she’s had lots of men.
have.translation[1].definitions[25].defi: used to offer something to someone
have.translation[1].definitions[25].exam: Won’t you have a drink before you go?
Please have a seat, and the doctor will be right with you.
have.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: USAGE: Have got, have
have.translation[1].note_box[0].items[0]: In British spoken English, people usually use have got instead of have for many of its meanings Have sounds more formal and is the usual choice in written English You say  You write
have.translation[1].note_box[0].items[1]: In questions in British spoken English, Have you got ? is often used instead of Do you have ? You say  You write
have.translation[1].note_box[0].items[2]: In negative sentences in British spoken English, you use haven't got or hasn't got You say  You write
He does not have any money
have.translation[1].note_box[0].items[3]: Have got is mainly used in the present tense In the past tense you usually use had, and in the future you usually use will have
have.translation[1].note_box[0].items[4]: In American English, have got is much less common It is used when you want to emphasize what you are saying  It is also often used in the phrase have got to  (=have to)
have.translation[1].note_box[0].items[5]: In negative sentences, British speakers often say I haven't got  where American speakers say I don't have  In questions, British speakers say Have you got ? where American speakers say Do you have ?
have.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if you have to do something, you must do it because it is necessary or because someone makes you do it
have.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: We don’t have to rush – there’s plenty of time.
I hate having to get up early in the morning.
If you earn more than £5,000, you will have to pay tax.
I’ve got to be at the hospital at 4 o'clock.
It’ll have to be on a Sunday. I’ll be working every other day.
have.translation[2].definitions[0].note_: In writing, people often prefer to say someone is forced to do something or is obliged to do something, as these sound more formal than have to do something:
have.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: used to say that it is important that something happens, or that something must happen if something else is to happen
have.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: There has to be an end to the violence.
There will have to be a complete ceasefire before the Government will agree to talks.
You have to be good to succeed in this game.
have.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: used to tell someone how to do something
have.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: First of all you have to mix the flour and the butter.
have.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: used to say that you are sure that something will happen or something is true
have.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: House prices have to go up sooner or later.
This has to be a mistake.
You have got to be joking!
No one else could have done it – it had to be Neville.
have.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: used to suggest that someone should do something because you think it would be enjoyable or useful
have.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: You’ll have to come and meet my wife some time.
have.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: used when something annoying happens in a way that things always seem to happen
have.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: Of course, it had to happen today, when all the shops are shut.
have.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: used to say that only one thing or person is good enough or right for someone
have.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: For Francesca it has to be the Ritz – nowhere else will do.
